section.title: Text Search
section.para: Open a new search window with C f and enter the word or phrase you wish to search for in the search field.
Alternatively, select a word or phrase in the , , or pane and hit Cf. The selection is automatically entered in the search field.
You can have several search windows open at the same time. Use SCf to call the last search window.
Click the dropdown arrow of the Search for: field to access the last ten searches.
Click on Search or hit Enter when the search field is selected to start the search.
Matches will be displayed in bold blue characters.
The search window has its own menus:

listitem.para: File > Search for Selection ( C f ): the current selection is inserted in the search field.
File > Close ( C w ): close the search window (same as Esc).
Edit > Insert Source ( S C i ): insert the content of the current source segment.
Edit > Replace with Source ( S C r ): replace the contents of the search field with those of the current source segment.
Edit > Create Glossary Entry ( S C g ): add a new glossary item. See for details.
Edit > Reset Options: reset the search window options.

section.title: Search types and options
section.para: Use the radio buttons to select the type of search. The following search types are available:

listitem.para: Search for the string exactly as it was entered in the search field.
It is equivalent to a web search enclosed in quotation marks.
Search for segments containing each of the search terms separated by a space.
It is equivalent to a web search without quotation marks.
Treat the search string as a regular expression.
Regular expressions are a very powerful way to search for general or complex patterns rather than exact strings. See for details.

section.para: The * and ? characters can be used in both exact and keyword searches:

listitem.para: '*' matches zero or more characters, from the current position up to the end of a word. The search term 'run*', for example, matches 'run', 'runs' and 'running'.
'?' matches any single character. For instance, 'run?' matches 'runs', as well as the 'runn' portion of 'running' or 'runner'.

warning.para: The '*' and '?' characters have a special meaning in regular expressions. Therefore, the wild card searches described above only apply to exact and keyword searches.

section.title: Options

listitem.para: Only returns results with the same letter case as the search terms.
Space characters in search terms with match both a normal space and a non-breacking space (\u00A) character.
Search in the source segments.
Search in the target segments.
Search in notes attached to segments.
Search in comments attached to segments.
Search in both translated and untranslated segments.
Search only in translated segments.
Search only in untranslated segments.
Every segment is displayed individually, even if it is a duplicate found in either the same document or a different document in the project.
The name of the file containing the segment is found is displayed above each result.
You can check Memory to include the project memory (), TMs to include other translation memories located in the folder, and Glossaries to include the glossaries located in the folder, in the search.
Search in a single file or in a folder containing several files.

File searches (unlike translation memories), are limited to files in source file formats supported by OmegaT. Consequently, TMX files are excluded from file searches since OmegaT does not recognize them as a source file format despite supporting them for translation memories.

section.para: You can click on the Show Advanced Options button to select additional criteria such as the person who authored or changed the translation, the date and time of translation (modification), or whether to exclude orphan segments.
Checking the Full/Half width char insensitive option will return results that match both the full- and half-width forms (CJK characters) of the characters in the search terms.
Number of matching segments sets the maximum number of matches displayed in the search result area.

section.title: Search results display
section.para: Matches are displayed in their order of appearance in the project. For translated segments, the original text is displayed above the translated text. Only the source text is displayed for untranslated segments.
You can use the standard ( C n , C p ) shortcuts to move from one segment to another in the search window.
Double-click on a segment to open it in the .
Check the Auto-sync with Editor box at the bottom of the search window to have selected segments open in the Editor automatically.
Check the Back to the initial segment on close box to automatically return to the segment you were in when you started the search after you close the window.

section.title: Filter
section.para: Click on the Filter button to show only the matching search result segments in the . To remove the filter, click the Remove Filter button or reload the project.
